comments:
LGST206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills. 

Student feedback was overwhelmingly positive for this course describing it as “life-changing,” “mindblowing,” and “one of the best learning experiences at Penn.” Students reported learning a great deal about negotiations in practical settings and thoroughly enjoyed the material.

Professsor Shell was prasied by his students for his impeccable knowledge and gift for teaching. One student commented that Professor “Shell breeds a culture of learning and self-improvement rather than competition.” 

Course requirements include graded in-class negotiations, two quizzes, four one-page papers, and a final paper. A small number of students expressed dislike for the quizzes, claiming that they were an exercise of “long-lasting focus.” Overall, the feedback for this course was extremely positive, however.

LGST206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills. 

Student feedback for this course was overwhelmingly positive. One student stated it was the “most valuable course in my college career. Students commented on how much they applied what they learned in class in the outside world. Students liked how the grades were not based on the negotiation outcomes which allowed them to focus on learning sound negotiating skills rather than trying to win at all costs. One student appreciated “learning the human dynamics in negotiating than just the bottom line.” Students commented on how much they applied what they learned in class in the outside world. 

Students praised Professor Taheripour for being “amazing,” “inspirational,” and a “highly gifted lecturer.” Although one student wished that she made herself more available outside of class, many commented on her dedication to students.

Course requirements include peer evaluations, six one-page journal entries, a midterm examination, and an analytical paper. Grading was a point of concern for some students who felt it was “arbitrary.” Some students wished that more weight was placed on the negotiations, which were not graded. Overall, students were extremely satisfied with the class.
